meanings.definition: Relating to or characteristic of populism.
meanings.sent1: The candidate's speech had a strong populistic appeal to the working class voters.
meanings.sent2: The new political party's platform was focused on populistic ideals that resonated with the general public.
meanings.sent3: The populistic approach to marketing the product made it seem like a must-have for everyone.
meanings.sent4: Her leadership style was described as populistic, always putting the needs of the people first.
meanings.sent5: The populistic nature of the movement swept through the nation, uniting people from all walks of life.

meanings.definition: Appealing to or aimed at ordinary people.
meanings.sent1: The company's populistic advertising campaign featured everyday people enjoying their products.
meanings.sent2: The speech was designed to have a populistic tone, connecting with the average citizen's concerns.
meanings.sent3: It was amusing to see the usually reserved professor take on a populistic approach to teaching.
meanings.sent4: Her smile was as warm and populistic as a hug from an old friend.
meanings.sent5: The populistic message of the play touched the hearts of the audience, leaving them feeling understood and valued.

meanings.definition: Involving or representing the common people.
meanings.sent1: The artist's work had a populistic theme, depicting scenes from everyday life.
meanings.sent2: The politician's speech was filled with populistic references to the struggles of the working class.
meanings.sent3: It was a fun twist to see the usually elite event take on a populistic vibe.
meanings.sent4: Her dress was a populistic masterpiece, made from fabrics that the common people could afford.
meanings.sent5: The populistic movement gave a voice to those who had long been ignored by the establishment, empowering the marginalized communities.
